The '''2020s anti-LGBTQ movement in the United States''' is an ongoing [[Backlash (sociology)|political backlash]] from [[Social conservatism in the United States|social conservatives]] against [[LGBTQ movements]]. It has included [[Legislature|legislative]] proposals of [[Bathroom bill|bathroom use restrictions]], [[Transgender rights in the United States|bans on gender-affirming care]], [[Anti-LGBTQ curriculum laws in the United States|anti-LGBTQ curriculum laws]], [[Drag panic|laws against drag performance]]s, [[2021–2023 book banning in the United States|book bans]], [[boycott]]s, and [[LGBTQ grooming conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories around grooming]].<ref>{{cite news |title=America's far right is increasingly protesting against LGBT people ==Grooming conspiracy theory== {{main|LGBTQ grooming conspiracy theory}} {{LGBTQ sidebar|attitudes}}
Members of the far-right and a number of mainstream [[Conservatism|conservatives]], mostly in the United States, have used the term "groomer" to falsely accuse LGBTQ people, as well as their allies and progressives in general, of systematically using LGBTQ sex education and campaigns for LGBTQ rights as a method of [[child grooming]] and enabling [[pedophilia]]. Usage of this term increased in the 2020s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Romano |first1=Aja |title=The right's moral panic over "grooming" invokes age-old homophobia |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/23025505/leftist-groomers-homophobia-satanic-panic-explained |access-date=19 April 2024 |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=21 April 2022 |language=en}}</ref>
In the United States, the popularization of the term has been linked to [[Christopher Rufo]], who tweeted about "winning the language war", and [[James A. Lindsay]] in August 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2022/04/05/qanon-groomer-hawley-desantis-jackson/ |title=The QAnon catchphrases that took over the Jackson hearings |date=April 7, 2022 |orig-date=April 5, 2022 |author1=Donald Moynihan |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |place=Washington, D.C. |issn=0190-8286 |oclc=1330888409 |access-date=May 24, 2023 |archive-date=April 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230410145445/https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2022/04/05/qanon-groomer-hawley-desantis-jackson/ controversy]] in July 2021, [[Julia Serano]] noted a rise in false accusations of grooming directed towards transgender people, saying that it appeared as if there was a movement to "lay the also slurs LGBTQ people, supporters of LGBTQ youth,<ref name="Stahl-2022">{{cite web |last1=Stahl |first1=Jeremy |title=The Hate-Fueled and Hugely Influential World of Libs of TikTok |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/04/chaya-raichik-libs-tiktok-groomer-tweets.html |website=Slate Magazine |access-date=July 27, 2022 |language=en |date=April 27, 2022 |archive-date=July [[File:Libs of TikTok logo.jpg|thumb|Far-right anti-LGBTQ Twitter account [[Libs of TikTok]] (logo pictured) uses the term "groomers" as a pejorative for [[LGBTQ]] people.|left|200x200px]]
The conspiracy theory then moved into the American conservative mainstream, with a number of high-profile cases of its use in spring 2022, including its use by members of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].<ref name="Romano-2022">{{cite web |last1=Romano |first1=Aja |title=The right's moral panic over "grooming" invokes age-old homophobia |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/23025505/leftist-groomers-homophobia-satanic-panic-explained |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=April 21, 2022 |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |access-date=July 28, 2022 |archive-date=May 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230517125930/https://www.vox.com/culture/23025505/leftist-groomers-homophobia-satanic-panic-explained |url-status=live}}</ref> On February 24, the right-wing [[Heritage Foundation]] issued a tweet stating that the [[Florida Parental Rights in Education Act]] "protects young children from sexual grooming".<ref name="Mathis-Lilley-2022">{{Cite web |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/04/christina-pushaw-ron-desantis-libsoftiktok-groomer.html |title=How One Florida Woman With Twitter Problems Plunged Us Into a Nightmarish National Conversation About 'Grooming' |last1=Mathis-Lilley |first1=Ben |date=April 21, 2022 |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |access-date=May 24, 2023 |archive-date=May 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230528043711/https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/04/christina-pushaw-ron-desantis-libsoftiktok-groomer.html |url-status=live}}</ref> During the debate over the act, [[Christina Pushaw]], press secretary to the state's governor [[Ron DeSantis]], tweeted that anyone who opposes the act was "probably a groomer". In April 2022, [[Marjorie Taylor Greene]] referred to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] as "the party of killing babies, grooming and transitioning children, and pro-pedophile politics". Also that month, a group of [[Radical right (United States)|far-right]] extremists and conspiracy theorists held a demonstration at [[Disney World]] in which they accused Disney of grooming.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Alfonseca |first1=Kiara |title=Some Republicans use false 'pedophilia' claims to attack Democrats, LGBTQ people |date=May 7, 2022 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/republicans-false-pedophilia-claims-attack-democrats-lgbtq-people/story?id=84344687 |work= [[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |access-date=July 28, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230213101039/https://abcnews.go.com/US/republicans-false-pedophilia-claims-attack-democrats-lgbtq-people/story?id=84344687 |url-status=live}}</ref> Disney has been the focus of several other uses of the conspiracy{{snd}}[[Jim Banks]] and 19 other members of the [[Republican Study Committee]] published a letter to Disney accusing the corporation of "purposefully influencing small children with its political and sexual agenda".<ref name="Brooks-2022"/>
Since then, numerous right wing pundits have described the behavior of parents and teachers who support minors in their transgender identities as grooming, and the term "groomer" has widely been used ==Education==
=== Anti-LGBTQ curriculum laws === {{main|Anti-LGBTQ curriculum laws in the United States}} {{further|Censorship of school curricula in the United States}} [[File:Student protest Palm Harbor FL.jpg|thumb|right|A student protest at [[Palm Harbor University High School]] against the [[Florida Parental Rights in Education Act]]]]
In July 2022, a wave of anti-LGBTQ curriculum resurgence saw ten such laws beginning to take effect in six different states. Some states enacting these new laws appear to have mirrored similar laws from other states.<ref name="Washington Post-2022">{{Cite news |title=10 anti-LGBTQ laws just went into effect. They all target schools. |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2022/07/08/anti-lgbtq-education-laws-in-effect/ |access-date=July 8, 2022 |issn=0190-8286 |archive-date=July 9, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220709171121/https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2022/07/08/anti-lgbtq-education-laws-in-effect/ |url-status=live}}</ref>
In [[Florida]], the [[Florida Parental Rights in Education Act|Parental Rights in Education law]] and [[Florida Board of Education]] policy bans education on "sexual orientation" or "gender identity" ==Anti-trans laws== ===Gender transition=== [[File:Students Protest Anti-Trans Law (51934611549).jpg|thumb|Students in [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]] protesting an anti-trans law signed by Republican Governor [[Kim Reynolds]] in 2022]] As many as 13 U.S. states banned [[Transgender health care|gender affirming health care]] for [[transgender youth]] in the early-2020s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Paris |first1=Francesca |title=Bans on Transition Care for Young People Spread Across U.S. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 15, 2023 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/15/upshot/bans-transgender-teenagers.html#:~:text=Ten%20states%20in%20the%20past,surgery%20for%20people%20under%2018. |access-date=May 24, 2023 |archive-date=May 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524053546/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/15/upshot/bans-transgender-teenagers.html#:~:text=Ten%20states%20in%20the%20past,surgery%20for%20people%20under%2018. |url-status=live}}</ref>
==== Treatment for adults ==== Many [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] legislators across the country are increasingly proposing legislation that would restrict gender-affirming care for adults or make such treatments harder to access. However, no states have succeeded at outright banning gender-affirming care for adults in a way similar to what is being done with minors. Efforts to restrict adults' access to healthcare relies heavily on claims from self-described "[[gender-critical]]" organizations such as [[Genspect]] that young people should not be recognized as adults until they turn 25.<ref>{{cite news |last=Migdon |first=Brooke |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/3810926-transgender-youth-health-care-bans-have-a-new-target-adults/ |title=Transgender youth health care bans have a new target: adults |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=January 13, 2023 |access-date=March 5, 2024 |archive-date=December 29, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231229011130/https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/3810926-transgender-youth-health-care-bans-have-a-new-target-adults/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Goldman |first=Maya |url=https://www.axios.com/2024/01/10/trans-care-adults-red-states |title=States are limiting gender-affirming care for adults, too |website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |date=January 10, 2024 |access-date=February 5, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Lang |first=Nico |url=https://www.them.us/story/trans-adults-next-target-gop-war-on-gender-affirming-health-care |title=Trans Adults Are the Next Target in the GOP's War on Gender-Affirming Health Care |website=[[Them (website)|them.us]] |date=February 16, 2024 |access-date=March 10, 2024}}</ref>

As part of his [[Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign|2024 presidential campaign]], [[Donald Trump]] has stated that if elected, he will sign an executive order instructing every federal agency to cease the promotion of sex or gender transition at any age as well as ask Congress to pass a bill stating that the United States will only recognize two genders as determined at birth, and has promised to crackdown on gender-affirming care for all ages. In February 2024, the [[American Psychological Association]] approved a policy statement supporting unobstructed access to health care and evidence-based clinical care for transgender, gender-diverse, and nonbinary children, adolescents, and adults, as well as opposing state bans and policies intended to limit access to such care.<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 2024 |title=APA Policy Statement on Affirming Evidence-Based Inclusive Care for Transgender, Gender Diverse, and Nonbinary Individuals, Addressing Misinformation, and the Role of Psychological Practice and Science |url=https://www.apa.org/about/policy/transgender-nonbinary-inclusive-care |access-date=February 29, 2024 |website=[[American Psychological Association]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Reed |first1=Erin |title=World's largest psych association supports trans youth care |url=https://www.advocate.com/news/apa-gender-affirming-care |access-date=February 29, 2024 |magazine=[[The Advocate (magazine)|The Advocate]] |language=en}}</ref>
As of July 2024, 26 states had enacted some form of ban on gender-affirming care for minors, 19 of which were enacted in 2023.<ref name="Williams Institute-2023">{{Cite web |orig-date=October 19, 2023 |title=Nearly 100,000 transgender youth live in states that banned access to health care, sports, or school bathrooms in 2023 |url=https://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/press/trans-leg-summary-press-release/ |access-date=December 29, 2023 |website=Williams Institute |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-01-11 |title=Efforts to restrict transgender health care endure in 2024, with more adults targeted |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/nbc-out/out-politics-and-policy/efforts-restrict-transgender-health-care-endure-2024-adults-targeted-rcna133432 |access-date=2024-02-05 |website=NBC News |language=en}}</ref> However, 16 of these bans are being challenged in court as of January 2024.<ref name="KFF-2024">{{Cite web |title=The Proliferation of State Actions Limiting Youth Access to Gender Affirming Care |url=https://www.kff.org/policy-watch/the-proliferation-of-state-actions-limiting-youth-access-to-gender-affirming-care/ | date=January 31, 2024 |access-date=February 5, 2024 |website=[[Kaiser Family Foundation|KFF]] |language=en-US}}</ref> Furthermore, only 18 of the 26 states have complete bans which are fully in effect. Six states have only partial bans and two are currently blocked from taking effect. While some states have banned all forms of medical transition, others such as Arizona, Nebraska, New Hampshire and Georgia have banned only specific types such as hormone therapy or surgery. Six states have exceptions which allow minors who were already receiving gender affirming care prior to the ban to continue their treatments.<ref name="KFF-2024"/> Currently, all 26 states make exceptions for puberty blockers, hormones and surgery for cisgender and intersex children.<ref name="KFF-2024"/> Only one state, West Virginia, makes exceptions in cases of "severe dysphoria". There is also currently only one state, Missouri, that has a ban which is set to expire after a certain period of time. Nearly all states with restrictions include specific provisions with penalties for providers and 4 states include provisions directed at parents or guardians.<ref name="KFF-2024"/> An additional 4 states include laws/policies that impact school officials such as teachers and counselors, among others.<ref name="KFF-2024"/>
At the same time, many Democrat-controlled states have gone in the opposite direction and enacted laws protecting access to gender affirming care for minors and adults. These laws, often called "shield" laws, often explicitly combine protections for gender-affirming care and abortion and cover a variety of protections including protecting both providers and patients from being punished, mandating insurance providers to cover the procedures and acting as "sanctuary states" that protect patients traveling to the state from other states that have banned such treatments among other things.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Panetta |first=Grace |title=Lawmakers in blue states are linking protections for abortion and gender-affirming care |url=https://19thnews.org/2023/06/abortion-trans-health-care-shield-laws/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=[[The 19th]] |date=June 9, 2023 |language=en-US |archive-date=February 5, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240205155546/https://19thnews.org/2023/06/abortion-trans-health-care-shield-laws/ |url-status=live }}</ref> As of June 2024, 16 states and the District of Columbia have enacted "shield" laws.
Of the approximately 1.6 million Americans who are transgender, about 300,000 are under the age of 18.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hassan |first1=Adeel |date=June 27, 2023 |title=States Passed a Record Number of Transgender Laws. However, around 26,000 of those youth are currently still able to access care in their state due to court orders that prohibit enforcement of the laws. In an early example of an anti-trans bathroom bill, the [[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act]] in [[North Carolina]], was approved as a law in 2016. The bill, however, sparked widespread condemnation and threats of boycotts, and portions of the measure were repealed in 2017 as part of a compromise between the Democratic governor and Republican-controlled Legislature. Also in 2016, guidance was issued by the U.S. Departments of Justice and Education stating that schools which receive federal money must treat a student's gender identity as their sex (for example, in regard to bathrooms).<ref name="Terkel-2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/donald-trump-transgender_n_58ac4fe8e4b0a855d1d9d278 |title=Trump Administration Rescinds Protections For Transgender Students |work=[[HuffPost]] |first=Amanda |last=Terkel |date=February 22, 2017 |access-date=January 18, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120155803/https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-transgender_us_58ac4fe8e4b0a855d1d9d278 |archive-date=January 20, 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> This policy was revoked in 2017.<ref name="Terkel-2017" />

== Marriage == [[File:117th Congress 2nd session Senate roll call 362.svg|thumb|Map image of senatorial votes for the Respect for Marriage Act (2022)]] In response to a concurring opinion by Justice [[Clarence Thomas]] in ''[[Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization]]'' arguing the Court should reconsider ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'', Congress passed the [[Respect for Marriage Act]] in 2022.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sneed |first=Tierney |title=Supreme Court's decision on abortion could open the door to overturn same-sex marriage, contraception and other major rulings |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/06/24/politics/abortion-ruling-gay-rights-contraceptives/index.html |website=CNN |date=June 24, 2022 |access-date=July 18, 2022 |archive-date=June 24, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220624174858/https://www.cnn.com/2022/06/24/politics/abortion-ruling-gay-rights-contraceptives/index.html |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Gerstein |first1=Josh |title=Justice Thomas: SCOTUS "should reconsider" contraception, same-sex marriage rulings |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/06/24/thomas-constitutional-rights-00042256 |website=Politico |date=June 24, 2022 |access-date=July 18, 2022 |archive-date=July 18, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220718031321/https://www.politico.com/news/2022/06/24/thomas-constitutional-rights-00042256 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Carlisle |first1=Madeline |title=Clarence Thomas Signals Same-Sex Marriage and Contraception Rights at Risk After Overturning Roe v. == Public opinion == ===Polls and surveys=== An April 2021 [[PBS NewsHour]]/[[NPR]]/[[Marist poll|Marist]] poll with the question "Do you support or oppose legislation that would prohibit gender transition-related medical care for minors" found 66% of Americans would oppose a ban, including 69% of Democrats, 70% of Republicans, and 64% of Independents.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Loffman |first1=Matt |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/new-poll-shows-americans-overwhelmingly-oppose-anti-transgender-laws |title=New poll shows Americans overwhelmingly oppose anti-transgender laws |work=[[PBS NewsHour]] |date=16 April 2021}}</ref>
A February 2022 poll by [[LGBTQ]] support service [[The Trevor Project]] and [[Morning Consult]] found that 52 percent of American adults expressed some level of support for transgender minors having access to puberty blockers if it is recommended by their doctor and supported by their parents.<ref>{{Cite news |date=30 March 2022 |title=Poll: Majority of U.S. Adults Oppose Anti-LGBTQ Education Policies, Agree that Transgender Youth Should Have Access to Gender-Affirming Care |url=https://www.thetrevorproject.org/blog/poll-majority-of-u-s-adults-oppose-anti-lgbtq-education-policies-agree-that-transgender-youth-should-have-access-to-gender-affirming-care/ |access-date=August 30, 2022 |website=[[The Trevor Project]] |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=March 2022 |title=LGBTQ+ Content Bans and Gender-Affirming Medical Care |work=[[The Trevor Project]] and [[Morning Consult]] |url=https://www.thetrevorproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/TrevorProject_MorningConsult_ReportB1-1.pdf |access-date=October 27, 2022}}</ref>
A June 2022 [[Pew Research Center|Pew Research Poll]] found that most Americans were uncomfortable with the speed of change on issues related to transgender people, with young adults and Democrats being the most supportive of transgender issues and Republicans and people in the 55-64 years age group being the least supportive.<ref>{{Cite news |date=June 28, 2022 |title=Americans' Complex Views on Gender Identity and Transgender Issues |work=Pew Research Center |url=https://www.pewresearch.org/social-trends/2022/06/28/americans-complex-views-on-gender-identity-and-transgender-issues/ |access-date=November 25, 2024}}</ref>
According to the [[Public Religion Research Institute]] in February 2023, support for mandating that trans people use the bathroom corresponding to their gender assigned at birth rose among all religious groups, with white evangelical Protestants seeing the largest change, going from 41% in support to 72% in support between 2017 and 2021. 41% of total Americans held this stance, with 31% disagreeing, and 28% not taking either position.<ref name="WaPo-2023">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2023/02/21/trump-gender-lgbtq-identity/ |title=Trump is exploiting an anti-trans turn in public opinion |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 21, 2023 |access-date=July 13, 2023 |archive-date=February 23, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230223144538/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2023/02/21/trump-gender-lgbtq-identity/ |url-status=live}}</ref>
In a poll from [[Data for Progress]] in March 2023, when asked about the more than 400 pieces of anti-trans legislation working their way through statehouses, 64 percent of respondents, including 55 percent of Republicans, agreed with the statement "This is too much legislation. Politicians are playing political theater and using these bills as a wedge issue," while 25 percent agreed with the statement "This is the right amount of legislation. Politicians are dealing with a real danger that needs to be addressed." As a result, pollsters and strategists from both parties warned that Republican's intense focus on restricting the rights and health care of about 0.6 percent of the American population could risk putting off independents and swing voters in the next election.<ref>{{cite news |last=Saksa |first=Jim |title=Republicans' fixation on trans issues could backfire, pollsters say |url=https://rollcall.com/2023/03/31/republicans-fixation-on-trans-issues-could-backfire-pollsters-say/ |access-date=August 21, 2024 |website=[[Roll Call (newspaper)|Roll Call]] |date=March 31, 2023}}</ref>
A [[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]/[[Kaiser Family Foundation|KFF]] poll conducted in November 2022 found that 68 percent of adults oppose access to puberty-blocking medication for transgender children ages 10 to 14, and 58 percent oppose access to hormonal treatments for transgender children ages 15 to 17.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gans |first1=Jared |title=Majority of Americans oppose gender-affirming care for minors, trans women participating in sports: poll |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/3991685-majority-of-americans-oppose-gender-affirming-care-for-minors-trans-women-participating-in-sports-poll/ |access-date=June 3, 2023 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |agency=The Hill |date=May 6, 2023}}</ref>
In a January 2023 [[Deseret News]]/HarrisX poll, 55 percent of Americans supported banning gender hormone therapy for transgender minors with parental or guardian approval, while 45 percent opposed such a ban.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bates |first1=Suzanne |title=Transgender issues in schools and states: New poll shows how Americans feel |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230912191832/https://www.deseret.com/2023/1/18/23548597/transgender-issues-in-schools-and-states-new-poll |url=https://www.deseret.com/2023/1/18/23548597/transgender-issues-in-schools-and-states-new-poll |archive-date=September 12, 2023 |access-date=October 25, 2023 |website=[[Deseret News]] |date=January 19, 2023}}</ref>
A January 2023 [[Pew Research Center|Pew Research Poll]] found that black Democrats were less likely than other Democrats to believe that a person's gender can be different from their birth sex and more likely to say that their views on LGBT issues are determined by their religion.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gramlich |first=John |title=Black Democrats differ from other Democrats in their views on gender identity, transgender issues |url=https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/01/04/black-democrats-differ-from-other-democrats-in-their-views-on-gender-identity-transgender-issues/ |access-date=November 25, 2024 |website=Pew Research Center |date=January 4, 2023}}</ref>
A May 2023 poll by [[The Washington Post]]/[[Kaiser Family Foundation|KFF]] found that a majority of Americans support some anti-trans policies despite also claiming to oppose discrimination for trans people.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ring |first=Trudy |title=Poll Finds Majority of Americans Support Anti-Trans Policies Despite Claiming to Oppose Discrimination |url=https://www.advocate.com/news/transgender-poll-american-anti-trans |access-date=August 21, 2024 |website=The Advocate |date=May 8, 2024}}</ref>
A June 2023 [[Gallup, Inc.|Gallup poll]] found that while 26% of Americans think trans athletes should be allowed to play on sports teams that match their gender identity, polls in five battleground states conducted by [[The New York Times]]/[[Siena College]] found a majority of Americans think society should accept transgender people's gender identities.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Jeffrey M. |title=More Say Birth Gender Should Dictate Sports Participation |url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/507023/say-birth-gender-dictate-sports-participation.aspx |access-date=November 25, 2024 |website=Gallup, Inc. |date=June 12, 2023}}</ref><ref name="Villarreal">{{cite news |last=Villarreal |first= Daniel |title=The GOP is spending millions on transphobic ads. Polls suggest it may backfire. |url=https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2024/10/the-gop-is-spending-millions-on-transphobic-ads-polls-suggest-it-may-backfire/ |access-date=October 11, 2024 |website=[[LGBTQ Nation]] |date=October 9, 2024}}</ref>
A September 2023 poll by [[The 19th|19th News]]/[[SurveyMonkey]] found that 39 percent of American adults supported transgender minors having access to any kind of gender-affirming care, including puberty blockers, hormones, therapy, and surgery.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rummler |first1=Orion |title=How personal relationships influence views on gender-affirming care |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231022203135/https://19thnews.org/2023/09/poll-gender-affirming-care-transgender-personal-relationships/ |url=https://19thnews.org/2023/09/poll-gender-affirming-care-transgender-personal-relationships/ |archive-date=October 22, 2023 |access-date=October 25, 2023 |website=[[The 19th]] |date=September 18, 2023}}</ref> Another poll by The 19th/SurveyMonkey that same month found that in a survey of 20,000 American adults, 17 percent believed politicians should focus on restricting gender-affirming care, while 33 percent believed they should focus on protecting access to gender-affirming care. The rest believed politicians should not focus on trans issues at all.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wiggins |first=Christopher |title=Americans Don't Want Politicians Focusing on Transgender Issues, Survey Finds |url=https://www.advocate.com/news/americans-dont-focus-transgender-issues |access-date=August 21, 2024 |website=The Advocate |date=September 18, 2023}}</ref> A separate poll conducted by The 19th that month found that 7 in 10 Americans, including majorities in both major parties and independents, do not think politicians are informed enough about gender-affirming care to make fair policies on it.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Becker |first1=Amanda |last2=Barclay |first2=Mel Leonor |title=Americans don't trust politicians on abortion and gender-affirming care, poll finds |url=https://19thnews.org/2023/09/poll-politicians-abortion-gender-affirming-care-trust/ |access-date=August 21, 2024 |website=[[The 19th]] |date=September 18, 2023}}</ref>
A September 2023 poll conducted by [[SurveyUSA]] and sponsored by the anti-trans group, [[Women's Declaration International]], found that a majority of voters believe a person's sex is determined at birth and that sex and gender are the same thing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Strong Majorities Prefer Female-Only Interactions for Women, Girls in Athletics, Restroom, Other Situations |url=https://www.surveyusa.com/client/PollReport.aspx?g=42574e21-871e-4023-9ef2-d9b5b39f47c8 |access-date=November 25, 2024 |website=SurveyUSA |date=September 28, 2023}}</ref>
A February 2024 survey by [[YouGov]] found that a majority of Americans support laws and policies protecting transgender people from hate crimes and discrimination in employment, permitting transgender people to serve in the military, allowing government employees to use pronouns that match their gender identity and outlawing conversion therapy for transgender minors. However, it also found that a majority of Americans support laws and policies banning transgender women from women's sports and prisons, prohibiting minors from attending drag shows and creating a law that "defines gender as a person's sex assigned at birth". Additionally, the survey found that while 54% of Americans oppose allowing transgender minors to access gender-affirming care, only 45% support laws and policies banning the treatments for minors.<ref>{{cite news |last=Orth |first=Taylor |title=Where Americans stand on 20 transgender policy issues |url=https://today.yougov.com/politics/articles/48685-where-americans-stand-on-20-transgender-policy-issues |access-date=October 30, 2024 |website=[[YouGov]] |date=February 16, 2024}}</ref>
A March 2024 poll by [[GLAAD]] found that more than half of both registered and likely voters surveyed said they would not support a candidate who "speaks frequently about restricting access to health care and participation in sports for transgender youth."<ref>{{cite news |last=Migdon |first=Brooke |title=Most voters oppose candidates who campaign against transgender people: Poll |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/lgbtq/4516762-voters-transgender-lgbtq-2024-poll/amp/ |access-date=August 21, 2024 |website=The Hill |date=March 7, 2024}}</ref>
A [[Gallup, Inc.|Gallup Poll]] released in June 2024 found that over 60% of U.S. adults oppose banning gender-affirming care for minors, but also found that just 44% of U.S. adults believe that change one's gender is morally acceptable, with 56% of 18-29 year olds saying it is morally acceptable compared to 38% of adults over age 65.<ref>{{cite news |last=Brenan |first=Megan |title=Slim Majority of U.S. Adults Still Say Changing Gender Is Morally Wrong |url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/645704/slim-majority-adults-say-changing-gender-morally-wrong.aspx |access-date=November 10, 2024 |website=[[Gallup, Inc.]] |date=June 7, 2024}}</ref>
A June 2024 poll by the [[University of Chicago]] found that 70% of Democrats and 29% of Republicans supported laws that protect access to gender-affirming care for minors.<ref>{{cite news |last=Blake |first=Suzanne |title=Some Republicans Back Transgender Care for Kids in New Poll |url=https://www.newsweek.com/some-republicans-back-transgender-care-kids-poll-1909609 |access-date=November 10, 2024 |website=[[Newsweek]] |date=June 7, 2024}}</ref>
An October 2024 poll by the [[Human Rights Campaign|HRC]] found that only 5% of voters say they are concerned about gender-affirming care and 61% said they will not support candidates who support banning gender-affirming care, including 41% of Republicans. The poll also found that 70% of voters think that anti-LGBTQ+ legislation has gone too far and that politicians have targeted trans people to divide Americans and "maintain their political power."<ref name="Villarreal"/>
An October 2024 poll by [[Baldwin Wallace University]] in Ohio found that 60% of registered voters in Ohio supported schools teaching 6th-12th grade students about sexual orientation but only 43% supported teaching students in those same grades about gender identity. Additionally, the poll found that 51% of voters in Ohio believe parents should not have direct control over what books are in the school library and 55% believe that parents should not be able to stop schools from teaching topics that they do not like. The poll also found that 72% of voters in Ohio would oppose policies or laws allowing medical professionals to provide someone younger than 18 with medical care for a gender transition and 73% would oppose policies or laws allowing transgender athletes to play on the team that matches their gender identity and 56% would support policies or laws requiring public schools to notify parents if it is discovered that a student identifies with a gender that does not align with their biological sex.<ref>{{cite web|last=Washington|first=Julie|url=https://www.cleveland.com/metro/2024/10/ohioans-overwhelmingly-oppose-transgender-rights-protections-bw-poll-finds.html|title=Ohioans overwhelmingly oppose transgender rights protections, BW poll finds|website=[[Cleveland.com|Cleveland]]|date=11 October 2024|access-date=2024-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Ohio Pulse Poll |url=https://www.bw.edu/news/2024/10/october_ohio_pulse_poll-final.pdf |access-date=October 11, 2024 |website=[[Baldwin Wallace University]] |date=October 9, 2024}}</ref>
==Election campaigning and results== ===2024 presidential election=== During the [[2024 United States presidential election|2024 presidential election]], anti-trans advertisements became commonplace, with the Republican party making trans issues a top issue in their campaign, spending over $215 million dollars on anti-trans ads and more than on ads regarding housing, immigration, and the economy combined.<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 5, 2024 |title=Republicans Spent Nearly $215M on TV Ads Attacking Trans Rights This Election |url=https://truthout.org/articles/republicans-spent-nearly-215m-on-tv-ads-attacking-trans-rights-this-election/ |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=[[Truthout]] |language=en}}</ref> On the contrary, Democrats largely avoided discussing transgender issues during the election campaign period.<ref name="NBCNews"/><ref>{{Cite web |date=October 25, 2024 |title=Even if Harris isn't talking about gender, everyone else is |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2024-election/kamala-harris-talking-gender-election-rcna177139 |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=NBC News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=October 15, 2024 |title=The Harris Campaign Has Offered Trans People Almost Nothing |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/politics/kamala-harris-trans-rights-platform/ |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=[[The Nation]] |language=en}}</ref> The ads became especially common during the closing days of the race, often pushing disparaging claims about transgender healthcare, existence in society, and participation in sports.<ref>{{Cite news |last= |first= |title=Trump and allies are pouring millions into anti-trans election ads as election nears |url=https://abcnews.go.com/amp/US/trump-spends-millions-anti-trans-ads-despite-polls/story?id=115001816 |access-date=2024-10-30 |work=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-10-24 |title=Republicans have bet big on anti-trans ads. Voters hate them |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/republican-anti-trans-ads-voter-reaction-poll-b2635079.html |access-date=2024-10-30 |work=[[The Independent]] |language=en}}</ref> Democrats did not formerly respond to the ads during the campaign period. Former President [[Bill Clinton]] privately expressed concern about the ads and encouraged the Harris campaign to respond to it. However, he was told by the campaign that the ads "were not necessarily having an impact" and never addressed his concerns publicly. The Harris campaign had originally planned to release an ad responding, but the ad ended up performing poorly in internal tests and was ultimately never run.<ref name="j774">{{cite web |last1=Goldmacher |first1=Shane |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |last3=Swan |first3=Jonathan |title=How Trump Won, and How Harris Lost, the 2024 Presidential Election |website=The New York Times |date=2024-11-07 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/07/us/politics/trump-win-election-harris.html |access-date=2024-11-08}}</ref>
According to an analysis by [[Future Forward PAC|Future Forward]], the political slogan "[[Kamala is for they/them|Kamala is for they/them, President Trump is for you]]" was ranked as one of the Trump's most effective 30-second attack ads, shifting the race 2.7 percentage points in favor of Trump after viewers watched it.<ref name="j774" /> On the contrary, an analysis by [[Change Research]] studying the effects of the ads found that they did not sway swing voters.<ref>{{cite web |title=After a stinging loss, Democrats debate where to draw the line on transgender rights |website=[[Semafor (website)|Semafor]] |date=November 12, 2024 |url=https://www.semafor.com/article/11/12/2024/after-a-stinging-loss-democrats-debate-over-where-to-draw-the-line-on-transgender-rights#the-view-from-conservatives |access-date=November 14, 2024}}</ref> A study by Ground Media also found that the ads did not sway voters into supporting Republicans, but they did succeed at slightly eroding public support for trans people in general.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 24, 2024 |title=Anti-trans ads erode support for transgender people in America with no effect on presidential election: study |url=https://www.advocate.com/election/transphobic-ads-erase-transgender-attitudes |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=The Advocate |language=en}}</ref> David Rochkind, the CEO of Ground Media, gave a press release saying "What this demonstrates is that attacking the trans community isn't just a weak and feckless political strategy — it's a deeply cynical one. ... These ads weaponize trans-identity to sow fear and division, making our country less safe for everyone."<ref>{{cite web |title=Ground Media study finds Trump's anti-trans ad fails politically, but dangerously erodes public support for trans people |website=Ground Media |date=October 24, 2024 |url=https://www.ground.media/news/ground-media-study-finds-trumps-anti-trans-ad-fails-politically-but-dangerously-erodes-public-support-for-trans-people |access-date=November 12, 2024}}</ref> A poll by Blueprint surveyed the most important issues to voters and found that trans issues ranked second to last among young men.<ref>{{cite web |title=No Country for Young Men: 18-29-Year-Old Male Voters Pessimistic About America, Have Conventional Political Priorities, Love Obama |website=Blueprint |date=October 22, 2024 |url=https://blueprint2024.com/polling/man-survey-youth-10-22/ |access-date=November 12, 2024}}</ref> An October 2024 poll by [[Data for Progress]] found that a majority of voters from both major parties believe the government should stop involving themselves in the lives of trans people and that politicians should focus less on transgender issues and more on other issues like the economy. It also found that a majority of voters from both major parties believe republicans leaning so heavily on anti-trans ads is "sad and shameful".<ref name="LGBTQNation"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Transgender Issues Tabs |website=[[Data for Progress]] |date=October 21, 2024 |url=hhttps://www.filesforprogress.org/datasets/2024/10/dfp_transgender_issues_tabs.pdf |access-date=November 12, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Donald Trump is hammering Kamala Harris on trans issues. But voters say they don't care. |website=LGBTQ Nation |date=October 24, 2024 |url=https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2024/10/donald-trump-is-hammering-kamala-harris-on-trans-issues-but-voters-say-they-dont-care/ |access-date=November 14, 2024}}</ref> An October 2024 [[Gallup, Inc.|Gallup Poll]] surveying the most important issues to registered voters ahead of the 2024 presidential election found that of the 22 issues voters were asked about, transgender issues ranked last with only 18 percent of voters describing it as "extremely important". Democrats were also more likely than Republicans to say transgender issues were extremely important to them, 25% to 12%.<ref>{{cite news |last=Brenan |first=Megan |title=Economy Most Important Issue to 2024 Presidential Vote |url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/651719/economy-important-issue-2024-presidential-vote.aspx?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email |access-date=October 11, 2024 |website=[[Gallup, Inc.]] |date=October 9, 2024}}</ref> Another poll by [[Data for Progress]] found that a majority of voters from all parties agree with the statement "the government should be less involved in regulating what transgender people are allowed to do, including the health care they can receive." Additionally, it found that 80% of voters agreed with the statement "both Democrats and Republicans should spend less time talking about transgender issues and more time talking about voters' priority issues like the economy and inflation." It also found that a majority of voters trust Democrats more than Republicans to handle transgender issues 52% to 29% and that a majority of voters, including a majority of Independent voters, believe Republicans have a more extreme stance of transgender issues than Democrats.<ref>{{cite news |title=Voters Prefer Candidates Who Are Supportive of Transgender Rights, Think Recent Political Ads Have Gotten Mean-Spirited and Out of Hand |url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/651719/economy-important-issue-2024-presidential-vote.aspx?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email |access-date=November 27, 2024 |website=[[Data for Progress]] |date=October 24, 2024}}</ref>
[[Vox Media]] said that anti-trans ads have "no impact on whether people are likely to vote" and compared them to the "rising tide of fascism in the United States".<ref>{{cite web |title=The cruel truth behind Trump's new attacks on trans people |website=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 30, 2024 |url=https://www.vox.com/2024-elections/380861/trump-transphobic-anti-trans-ads-scapegoating |access-date=November 12, 2024}}</ref> Kelley Robinson, the president of the [[Human Rights Campaign]], called the ads "desperate" and accused Republicans of focusing on "sowing fear and chaos" instead of talking about other issues like the economy. Jay Brown, chief of staff at the Human Rights Campaign said that the ads have had a negative impact on the mental health of trans people due to it being "in their faces all the time." [[LGBTQ Nation]] called the ads "wildly unpopular" among voters and said "there is a solid chance that the fate of transgender rights could mirror that of gay rights, becoming a sport of "political albatross" that instantly kills support for candidates. As politicians become more anti-trans, some members of their base oppose them more — likely due to people perceiving this issue as irrelevant and mean-spirited."<ref name="LGBTQNation">{{Cite web |date=October 31, 2024 |title=Anti-trans ads are unpopular with voters, but are still deepening anti-trans outlooks |url=https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2024/10/anti-trans-ads-are-unpopular-with-voters-but-are-still-deepening-anti-trans-outlooks/ |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=[[LGBTQ Nation]] |language=en}}</ref>
These ads led two Democrat politicians, [[Sherrod Brown]] and [[Colin Allred]], to capitulate, ceding the issue at least partially to the Republican position.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Anti-trans attack ads haven't won the GOP anything. Dems should stop acting scared. |url=https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/amp/rcna175554 |work=MSNBC}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=GOP ads on transgender rights are dominating airwaves in the election's closing days |url=https://www.npr.org/2024/10/19/g-s1-28932/donald-trump-transgender-ads-kamala-harris |work=NPR}}</ref> After Donald Trump won the 2024 election, two Democrat politicians, [[Tom Suozzi]] and [[Seth Moulton]], partially blamed their party's loss on their support for trans issues. Other Democrat politicians and human rights organizations disputed these claims, saying polls showed that trans issues were not important to most voters and that voters were instead mobilized to vote for Trump due to other issues like inflation and the economy.<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 7, 2024 |title=2 Democrats speak out against transgender athletes after Trump win |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4979665-democrats-transgender-athletes/amp/ |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=The Hill |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=November 7, 2024 |title=Suozzi says Democrats lost votes for supporting 'biological boys' playing on girls' sports teams |url=https://www.cityandstateny.com/politics/2024/11/suozzi-says-democrats-lost-votes-supporting-biological-boys-playing-girls-sports-teams/400930/ |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=[[City & State]] |language=en}}</ref> Texas Democratic Party Chair, [[Gilberto Hinojosa]] also expressed anti-transgender sentiments following the 2024 election. Hinojosa subsequently apologized for his comments and resigned from his position after receiving backlash from other Democrats and LGBTQ advocacy groups. The Harris campaign's LGBTQ engagement director, Sam Alleman, urged voters not to blame trans people for Harris' loss in the election saying "Please do not blame trans issues or trans people for why we lost. ... No exit polling or data is showing this as a significant decision point for voters."<ref name="NBCNews">{{Cite web |date=November 8, 2024 |title=Some Democrats blame party's position on transgender rights in part for Harris' loss |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/nbc-out/out-politics-and-policy/democrats-blame-partys-position-transgender-rights-part-harris-loss-rcna179370 |access-date=2024-11-10 |website=NBC News |language=en}}</ref>
An [[NBC News]] exit poll for the 2024 election found that [[Kamala Harris]] garnered more support from LGBTQ voters than any other presidential candidate in history, with 86% of LGBTQ voters backing Harris and 12% backing Donald Trump - a margin 15% larger than the edge [[Joe Biden]] had over Trump in 2020.<ref>{{Cite news |title=LGBTQ voters moved away from Trump as other Americans embraced him |url=https://www.washingtonblade.com/2024/11/06/lgbtq-voters-moved-away-from-trump-as-other-americans-embraced-him/ |work=Washington Blade}}</ref>

=== International === After a ten-day tour in which he met with State officials in Alabama, Florida, and California in August 2022, [[Victor Madrigal-Borloz]], a [[United Nations special rapporteur|United Nations Independent Expert]] on protection against violence and discrimination, warned about the erosion of LGBT rights in the United States.<ref name="UN Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner">{{cite web |title=United States: UN expert warns LGBT rights being eroded, urges stronger safeguards |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2022/08/united-states-un-expert-warns-lgbt-rights-being-eroded-urges-stronger |website=UN Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner |publisher=[[United Nations]] |access-date=June 15, 2023 |archive-date=October 11, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221011182808/http://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2022/08/united-states-un-expert-warns-lgbt-rights-being-eroded-urges-stronger |url-status=live}}</ref> Madrigal-Borloz stated, "I am deeply alarmed by a widespread, profoundly negative riptide created by deliberate actions to roll back the human rights of LGBT people at state level.
